title: Fix file descriptor leaks when using URL connections
body:
The JVM keeps a cache of URL connections, which keeps
the underlying files open for the lifetime of the VM
unless the `setUseCaches(false)` method is used.

This change makes it possible to reuse the Groovy compiler,
e.g. embedded in the Gradle daemon without preventing files
from being deleted on Windows.

title: Release 2.5.0 related fixes
body: Some recent commits seem to cause problems with the Nextflow 2.5.0 snapshot builds on the CI server. One can lead to a NPE (commit 90486ae1075d14a62d14452abfea0c27485a67b5) because fieldNode can be reassigned `null` after the `instanceof` check. Another change (commit 57cfd2a3e4d985b3248569ea1d92b02c59627703) seems to have caused an issue with assigning parameterized types.

title: Optimize generation of Groovydoc
body:
There's a lot to say about Groovydoc, but worst of all, its performance is terrible. This PR is an attempt to fix part of it.

Before my changes: https://scans.gradle.com/s/msfs2nf5mqmxw (3m35s)
After my changes: https://scans.gradle.com/s/a7pi5g6bb7bbu (53s)

@paulk-asert I'm leaving the review/merge to you as I spent already too much time on this. Given the improvements, I wouldn't mind a backport to 2.5!

title: Groovy 8562 wrong closure delegation for property access and compile static
body:
Roundup:

The StaticTypeCheckingVisitor would not look consider FieldNode to potentially delegate to a different Field. I think this could only occur for name collisions, i.e. the owner has a field with the same name as the delegate.
Calling tryVariableExpressionAsProperty solved this, however this broke other tests. To solve this I cheked IMPLICIT_RECEIVER, if unset and PROPERTY_OWNER is present, checkOrMarkPrivateAccess must be called to ensure the accessors are generated.

The VariableExpressionTransformer ignored delegation metadata when a private field accessor was present. I inversed that logic to give delegation metadata precedence over private field accessors.

Build passes https://travis-ci.org/MeneDev/groovy/builds/382561549

title: GROOVY-8509: SC error call to protected method from same package
body:
Because they were closely related, this PR also includes the following:

1. A change to the fix introduced by GROOVY-7883 (b1d1232770aa) to prevent filtering protected methods in the `StaticTypeCheckingVisitor` if caller is in the same package. From the same commit, removes the test `Groovy7883Bug#test3` because it should compile and the new test introduced for GROOVY-8509 in `MethodCallsStaticCompilation` takes it place.

1. A change to revert groovy.sql.Sql#asList (b1d1232770aa) back to `protected`. Fix for GROOVY-7883 enforced visibility for method calls in `TypedChecked` and `CompileStatic` modes. Test was originally put in place to verify the added ClosureParams, so changed test to access method via subclass so that the access modifier for the method can remain protected. I think the spirit of the test is preserved in this case without having to open access to the method under test.

title: GROOVY-8561: Support java-like array
body:
## Background
As we all know, Java array is one of features widely applied in Java projects. In order to improve the compatibility with Java(Copy & Paste), the PR on the new Parrot parser will make Groovy support java-like array. 
## Examples
### One-Dimensional array
```groovy
String[] names = {'Jochen', 'Paul', 'Daniel'}
assert ['Jochen', 'Paul', 'Daniel'].toArray() == names
```
```groovy
String[] names = {'Daniel'} // Note: this is an array, not a closure
assert ['Daniel'].toArray() == names
```
```groovy
String[] names = {} // Note: this is an array, not a closure
assert 0 == names.length
```
### Two-Dimensional array
```groovy
int[][] data = {
    {1, 2, 3},
    {4, 5, 6},
    {7, 8, 9},
    new int[] { 10, 11, 12 },
    {13, 14, 15}
}
assert [1, 2, 3].toArray() == data[0]
assert [4, 5, 6].toArray() == data[1]
assert [7, 8, 9].toArray() == data[2]
assert [10, 11, 12].toArray() == data[3]
assert [13, 14, 15].toArray() == data[4]
```
```groovy
int[][] data = new int[][] {
    {1, 2, 3},
    {4, 5, 6},
    {7, 8, 9},
    new int[] { 10, 11, 12 },
    {13, 14, 15}
}
assert [1, 2, 3].toArray() == data[0]
assert [4, 5, 6].toArray() == data[1]
assert [7, 8, 9].toArray() == data[2]
assert [10, 11, 12].toArray() == data[3]
assert [13, 14, 15].toArray() == data[4]
```
```groovy
int[][] data = {
    {3},
    {6},
    {9},
    new int[] {12},
    {15},
    {}
}
assert [3].toArray() == data[0]
assert [6].toArray() == data[1]
assert [9].toArray() == data[2]
assert [12].toArray() == data[3]
assert [15].toArray() == data[4]
assert 0 == data[5].length
```
### Annotation array
```groovy
import java.lang.annotation.RetentionPolicy
import java.lang.annotation.Retention

@Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)
public @interface PropertySource {
    String value();
}

@Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)
public @interface PropertySources {
    PropertySource[] value();
}

@PropertySources({
    @PropertySource("classpath:1.properties"),
    @PropertySource("file:2.properties")
})
public class Controller {}

def propertySources = Controller.getAnnotation(PropertySources).value()
assert 2 == propertySources.length
def values = propertySources.collect { it.value() }
assert ['classpath:1.properties', 'file:2.properties'] == values
```
### More array examples
Here are some tests[[1]](https://github.com/danielsun1106/groovy/blob/f20deb8bd6a1a90a4bfee8458e13438f7adf3732/subprojects/parser-antlr4/src/test/resources/core/Array_02x.groovy) [[2]](https://github.com/danielsun1106/groovy/blob/c78b95888a176d05b3fd410f45866b2ceed8344c/subprojects/parser-antlr4/src/test/resources/core/Annotation_11x.groovy) for reference.
## Limitation
The array type must be specified when declaring array, e.g.
```groovy
int[][] a = {{1, 2, 3}, {4, 5, 6}}  // valid
def a = {{1, 2, 3}, {4, 5, 6}}   // invalid
```

## Known breaking changes
@paulk-asert  added some more details about breaking changes and suggested alternatives in the jira issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-8561
### 1. `Closure` array in the dynamic mode
#### Before
  ```groovy
Closure[] y = { {-> 1 + 1 } }
assert y[0].call().call() == 2
  ```
#### After
  ```groovy
Closure[] y = { {-> 1 + 1 } }
assert y[0].call() == 2
  ```
### 2. `String` array in the dynamic mode
#### Before
  ```groovy
String[] a = {}
assert 1 == a.length
assert a[0].contains('closure')
  ```
#### After
  ```groovy
String[] a = {}
assert 0 == a.length
  ```
## Provisos(by @paulk-asert )
* we need to update the breaking changes section of 3.0.0 release notes on the website (site/src/site/releasenotes/groovy-3.0.adoc) to include the cases listed in GROOVY-8561
* we need to update the "Array initializers" section of core-differences-java.adoc (we need to explain what cases remain - obviously if no array type is specified is one case - I haven't checked whether Java allows arrays of lambdas or something similar which we may not support - I don't believe so but haven't researched into it)
* we need to update the "Arrays" section of core-syntax.adoc (I think we need to indicate that square brackets is the idiomatic approach and also explicitly say that closure is the default interpretation of curly braces unless the array target type can be inferred from the context.)

title: GROOVY-8422: Incorrect properties copy in Sql.newInstance
body:
The provided Properties should be passed to the DriverManager as-is.
A copy is only needed when changes are made to the provided Properties
in order to mask sensitive information for logging purposes.

title: GROOVY-8475: unable to instantiate objects using the "new" keyword in groovysh
body: PR #100 was merged into 2_5_X and comments on GROOVY-7562 indicate it wasn't merged into 2_4_X due to binary compatibility concerns. I think this backport addresses those concerns and this PR is targeted only for the 2_4_X branch.

title: Fix ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException in CallSiteWriter.getCreateArraySignature()
body:
It would throw `ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException` if the `numberOfArguments` exceed 255,
but there is no check for array index and it's hard to get the root cause to users.

We should throw a more readable exception here.

title: Fix XmlParser default constructor Javadoc
body: Currently, Javadoc says it creates "non-validating and non-namespace-aware" parser, but in fact, it _is_ namespace aware.

title: Documentation: fix style-guide range example
body:
e674d77 added more information about ranges
but included erroneous code for `range.size()`.

The style guide does not seem to have tests associated like some of the other
docs. If you want me to create a test, please give me some guidance.

I don't think code sample from e674d77 was tested. It was probably just
an ad hoc example written on the fly.

title: Support native lambda in static compilation mode
body:
Current implementation has supported:

* common scenarios of Java's lambda
* modifying non-final local variable
* callable lambda

Here are the tests:
https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/native-lambda/src/test/groovy/transform/stc/LambdaTest.groovy
